title: 108_hr1106
content: The "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" and involves the conveyance of facilities. The "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" requires the Secretary of the Interior to convey water distribution and drainage facilities to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho. If the conveyance is not completed by a certain date, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay. The Secretary will require the District to pay administrative costs for the conveyance and related activities, as well as the value of facilities to be transferred. The District must also pay the lesser of the remaining obligations owed to the United States or $280,000. Amounts received will be deposited into the Reclamation Fund. In conveying the Teton Exchange Wells, the Secretary will also transfer a water permit and equipment to the District. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions are met. Prior to conveyance, environmental reviews must be completed. Liability issues are addressed in the agreement. SEC. 7. The United States will not be liable for damages related to conveyed facilities, except for negligence prior to conveyance. SEC. 8. District's water supply eligibility increased without altering existing contracts. SEC. 9. Drought management planning required. Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders in the Henry's Fork watershed to initiate a drought management planning process. Within 18 months, a final drought management plan will be submitted to Congress. The Act does not affect existing rights or the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes' water rights based on treaties or laws. Conveyances under the Act will not impact irrigation districts' water rights.
